title: 1992 Summer Olympics national flag bearers
text:
During the Parade of Nations portion of the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">1992 Summer Olympics opening ceremony</a>, athletes from each country participating in the Olympics paraded in the arena, preceded by their flag. The flag was borne by a sportsperson from that country chosen either by the <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a> or by the athletes themselves to represent their country.
Parade order.
As the nation of the <a href="1896%20Summer%20Olympics">first</a> modern <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a> entered the stadium first; whereas, the host nation <a href="Spain%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">Spain</a> marched last. Other countries entered in alphabetical order in the <a href="French%20language">French language</a>, instead of both <a href="Catalan%20language">Catalan</a> and <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> (despite that these languages had been displayed on the name boards and used to announce the country names), due to the political sensitivity surrounding the use of Catalan. Athletes from <a href="Independent%20Olympic%20Participants%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">Independent Olympic Participants</a> did not attend the parade of nations, but still competed at the Games. The <a href="Unified%20Team%20at%20the%201992%20Summer%20Olympics">Unified Team</a> that was composed of former Soviet states, marched with Olympic flag, then followed by 12 flag bearers carrying the flags of 12 <a href="Post-Soviet%20states">nations</a>.
Whilst most countries entered under their <a href="List%20of%20sovereign%20states">short names</a>, a few entered under more formal or alternative names, mostly due to political and naming disputes. The <a href="Republic%20of%20China">Republic of China</a> (commonly known as Taiwan) entered with the compromised <a href="Chinese%20Taipei">name</a> and <a href="Chinese%20Taipei%20Olympic%20flag">flag</a> of "Chinese Taipei" ("Taipei chinois") under T so that they did not enter together with <a href="Two%20Chinas">conflicting</a> <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">People's Republic of China</a> (commonly known as China), which entered as the "People's Republic of China" ("République Populairé de Chine") under C. The <a href="Republic%20of%20the%20Congo">Republic of the Congo</a> entered as the "Republic of the Congo" ("République du Congo") while the <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20Congo">Democratic Republic of Congo</a> entered under its former name, <a href="Zaire">Zaire</a>.
